awd_titl_txt: Enabling Hydrogen Gas Production from Seawater Using Electrolytes Contained by Reverse Osmosis Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
The production of hydrogen gas is a significant component of global energy consumption and carbon emissions, accounting for 1% of global energy use. More than half this hydrogen is used to make fertilizer, and nearly all hydrogen gas is currently produced from fossil fuels. However, hydrogen gas can be produced from water using renewable electricity sources in a process called electrolysis, which splits water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen gases. The relative abundance of affordable wind energy, solar arrays, and seawater at offshore and coastal locations make them ideal sites for hydrogen gas production by this approach. However, the cost of hydrogen production by using a water electrolyzer must be reduced to make it economically competitive with other methods. Also, the production of toxic chemical byproducts from the chloride salts in seawater must be avoided. To meet these demands, the membranes typically used in electrolyzer systems will be replaced with the relatively inexpensive, salt-rejecting membranes commonly used for reverse osmosis (RO) seawater desalination. The use of RO membranes represents a fundamentally new approach to water electrolysis for hydrogen gas production. The RO membranes can be used to contain the seawater salts so that they do not react to form chemicals that are toxic or that could damage the membranes. This use of these ion-size selective RO membranes could have a large impact on methods for hydrogen gas production as well as other electrochemical separation technologies. This project, therefore, addresses a critical societal need for hydrogen gas production using a sustainable process. An educational platform will also be developed to engage the public in a conversation about energy use. The platform is expected to enhance general understanding of how our daily energy use can be modified to reduce fossil fuel use and carbon dioxide emissions.

This research project will develop a new seawater electrolysis approach to reduce the cost of water electrolyzers.  The objective will be accomplished by eliminating the use of costly proton exchange membranes and containing the anolyte to avoid chlorine gas production from chloride salts in seawater. To accomplish these goals, the proton exchange membrane will be replaced with a reverse osmosis (RO) membrane that can exclude ions while allowing proton ion transport between the electrodes, balancing charge between the electrolytes. The anolyte is contained by the RO membrane so that only oxygen gas evolution occurs in that compartment, and hydrogen gas evolution from seawater occurs in the catholyte, enabled by proton transport through the RO membrane. This approach, therefore, uses RO membranes for simultaneous salt ion retention and charged ion (proton) transport. Gas transport is avoided between the chambers and the RO membrane enables direct pressurized production of hydrogen. Water replacement in the anolyte can be accomplished by balancing osmotic pressure to achieve forward osmosis or by intermittent pressure adjustments between the two chambers. Preliminary data support this claim that some RO membranes have sufficiently low internal resistance to support high current densities (>100 Amps per square centimeter). Methods are proposed to reduce crossover of salts and improve membrane performance through nanoscale engineering of the membrane surface and supporting structures. This RO membrane approach could make hydrogen gas production from water electrolysis using renewable energy cost-competitive with steam reforming using fossil fuels, which would have a great societal benefit. Another project goal with broad applications is to enhance energy literacy of the public by exploring energy use based in terms of a daily energy unit, D, which ranges from 1 (food for one person) to 106 (energy normalized per person in the USA per day). Materials will be developed for an undergraduate seminar class, and a website and videos will be developed aimed at assisting STEM students in understanding energy used based on D and the carbon dioxide emissions unit, C (daily carbon dioxide emissions from one person).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Conventional hydrogen production methods emit carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas contributing to global warming. Electrolysis powered by renewable energy sources is a carbon-neutral method of hydrogen production but is hindered by its reliance on ultra-pure water and expensive membrane costs. In electrolysis, electricity is used to split water into hydrogen gas at the cathode and oxygen gas at the anode. Currently, ultra-pure water is required for electrolysis because chloride ions present in seawater can react at the anode to form chlorine gas and other oxidized chlorine species that can damage the electrolyzer. With our NSF award, we developed a new saltwater electrolyzer configuration that uses two different electrolytes separated by an affordable thin-film composite (TFC) membrane. In our configuration, saltwater is used as the electrolyte in the cathodic compartment where hydrogen is produced, and a fully oxidized salt solution is used in the anodic compartment where oxygen is produced. Using a fully oxidized salt solution, such as NaClO4, contained by a membrane prevents unwanted oxidation reactions from competing with the oxygen evolution reaction.

The TFC membranes we are studying to replace ion exchange membranes have a thin, polyamide active layer that rejects ions primarily based on size. These membranes are inexpensive because they are mass-produced for use in reverse osmosis water purification systems. Before our work, there were no known studies on how effectively thin-film composite membranes hinder salt ion transport in an applied current density, such as in electrolysis. We have completed several projects using the funding of our NSF award that develop saltwater electrolyzer technology with a contained anolyte, saltwater catholyte, and a TFC separating membrane hindering chloride ion transport to the anode.

Our initial projects studying TFC membranes for saltwater electrolysis addressed questions about the effectiveness of using these membranes to hinder chloride ion transport to the anode and their energy contribution compared to typical ion exchange membranes. We discovered that TFC membranes with resistances comparable to ion exchange membranes successfully electrolyzed saltwater in our new configuration with energy requirements like those with ion exchange membranes and faradaic efficiencies >95% for hydrogen production. This work resulted in a paper published in Energy and Environmental Science titled “Using reverse osmosis membranes to control ion transport during saltwater electrolysis” by Shi et al. We then analyzed the properties of different TFC membranes in electrochemical systems, such as their resistance, ion transport, and potential requirement during electrolysis, resulting in a publication in the Journal of Membrane Science titled “Electrochemical and hydraulic analysis of thin-film composite membranes in saltwater electrolysis” by Taylor et al. It was difficult to determine a way to predict the performance of a TFC membrane during electrolysis because each membrane has three composite layers with different thicknesses and synthesis methods depending on the manufacturer. We studied the energy and salt ion rejection qualities of the TFC backbone and active layers, and our results were published in “Relative insignificance of polyamide layer selectivity for seawater electrolysis applications” by Zhou et al. These works contributed to our understanding that TFC membranes can have vastly different performances in electrolysis depending on the thickness and porosity of their individual composite layers. The support layer thickness mainly contributed to energy requirements for electrolysis, while the active layer pore size determined chloride ion transport to the anode.

To further understand the membrane’s selective transport of water ions and salt ions during electrolysis, we collaborated with a research group at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) to model ion transport. Our validated model is described in our work titled “Modeling ion transport across thin-film composite membranes in saltwater electrolysis” by Taylor et al. The rapidly changing pH conditions during electrolysis causes the largest energy loss and controls chloride ion transport to the anode during the initial start-up phase. Once we gained a fundamental understanding of how salt and water ions selectively transport across TFC membranes during electrolysis, we developed methods for minimizing chloride ion transport across the membrane, including membrane modifications and optimized initial electrolyte composition. In our work titled “Reducing chloride ion permeation during seawater electrolysis using double-polyamide thin-film composite membranes,” we demonstrated how modifying the TFC structure to include an additional polyamide layer can reduce chloride ion permeation by 52%.

With our NSF award, we were able to share our research at several conferences over the past few years, including the American Chemical Society and the Physics of Membrane Processes workshop. Additionally, two postdocs and two graduate students developed their research skills and proficiency in techniques including COMSOL modeling, membrane characterization, ion chromatography, and electrochemical experimentation using a potentiostat. Our research can expand the use of these affordable TFC membranes to other electrochemical systems, and advance carbon neutral hydrogen production technology.
